set.p: A PLAY OF THE PRESENT DAY , IN FIVE ACTS , SCENE INDIVIDABLE SETTING FORTH THE STORY OF ONE MORNING IN THE EARLY SPRING

castItem.role: Time — An early morning in Spring
The Most Reverend the Lord Bishop of Lancashire

set.p: THE SCENE The scene , which remains unchanged throughout the play , is a room in the vicarage . Jacobean in character , its oak-panelling and beamed-ceiling , together with some fine pieces of antique furniture , lend it an air of historical interest , whilst in all other respects it speaks of solid comfort , refinement , and unostentatious elegance . Evidently the room of a rich man , who has , however , apparently come to some compromise on the difficult question of his entrance into the Kingdom of Heaven ; for the panelled walls possess , among other decorations , a richly ornamented crucifix , a Virgin and Child by an old master , certain saints in ecstasy , and a really remarkable modern oil-painting of the Divine Author of our religion . The main door of the room is at the back of the stage , somewhere towards the middle ; it opens upon a hall , at the further side of which one may perceive , through the open door of another room , a goodly collection of well-bound and learned-looking volumes — the vicar 's library . At the present moment these tomes of wisdom are inaccessible , as the library door is blocked up with unsightly mounds of earth , sewer-pipes , and certain workmen 's implements . The fact is , the vicarage has been greatly disturbed of late , owing to a defect in the drainage — an unsavory circumstance which receives further and regretful explication in the play itself . Returning , then , to the room , one may see , in addition to the main door described above , another door , to the right of stage , and near to the audience . The curious may be glad to learn that this leads into a drawing-room , and incidentally affords one more means of communication with the house . Another exit is provided on the opposite side of the stage [ left ] , where a couple of lofty French windows lead out into the garden . Above the drawing-room door is a fine old Jacobean mantel-piece : a fire burns brightly in the grate . To the left of the main door at the back is a long , low , mullioned window , through which one may see a blue sky , a thatched top or two of cottages , and the gray old tower of the church . Through the French windows are seen a gravel-walk , a lawn , trees , and a sun-dial . Of the essential furniture of the scene , there may be mentioned ; sideboard to right of main door ; table , right-centre of stage , with chairs ; arm-chair by fireplace ; settee , left , towards front ; and a long oak stool in the window . The various properties are described or implied in the text of the play .

div.head: THE FIRST ACT

stage.stage: As the curtain ascends , Rogers and Manson are discovered laying the table for breakfast , the lad being at the upper end of the table , facing the audience , Manson , with his back to the audience , being at the lower end . Rogers is an ordinary little cockney boy in buttons ; Manson is dressed in his native Eastern costume . His face is not seen until the point indicated lower down .
ROGERS [ glancing across curiously ] . Arskin ’ your pardon , Mr. Manson . . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Yes : what is it , Rogers ?

sp.speaker: ROGERS
sp.p: Funny thing — caw n't get it out of my ‘ ead as I 've knowed you somewhere before . Do n't scarcely seem possible , do it , Mr. Manson ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Many things are possible in this world , Rogers .

lg.l: That 's all right ; but ‘ ow long ‘ av ’ you been in England ,
Mr. Manson ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I landed late last night , if that 's what you mean .

sp.speaker: ROGERS
sp.p: Well , I never been in the continong of Asia , where you come from ; and there you are ! MANSONquietlyYes : here I am .

div.stage: He goes to the sideboard and busies himself with serviettes , mats , etc .

sp.speaker: ROGERS
sp.p: Perhaps it 's this reincarnytion the Daily Mail been writing about . Ever see the Daily Mail out there , Mr. Manson ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: No : we had few advantages .

sp.speaker: ROGERS
sp.p: Rum idea , reincarnytion ! Think , Mr. Manson , perhaps we wos lords once in ancient Babylon , you an ’ me !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: And now butler and page-boy , eh ? ROGERSscratching his headDoes seem a bit of a come-down , do n't it ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: That 's one way of looking at it .ROGERS , enticed of Satan , has conveyed a furtive spoonful of jam towards his mouth .Without turning .Is n't there jam in the kitchen , Rogers ? ROGERSscaredEvings ! E 've got eyes in ‘ is boots ! S'y , do you call it stealing , Mr. Manson ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Do you ?Persisting .Do you ?

div.stage: ROGERS drops the spoon and moves mournfully away from temptation .

sp.speaker: ROGERS
sp.p: ‘ Pon my word , Mr. Manson , you give me the fair creeps and no mistike !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: You will get over that when you knew me better .

sp.speaker: ROGERS
sp.p: Mr. Manson ! Do you mind if I arst you a question ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: No ; what is it ?

sp.speaker: ROGERS
sp.p: What d'you wear them togs for ? This ai n't India .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: People do n't always recognise me in anything else .

div.stage: He turns for the first time . His face is one of awful sweetness , dignity , and strength . There is the calm of a great mastery about him , suited to his habit as a servant .

sp.speaker: ROGERS
sp.p: Garn , Mr. Manson , that 's a bit orf ! Clothes do n't make all that difference , come now ! . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: They are the only things the people of this world see . ROGERSafter a pauseExcuse me , Mr. Manson , you mek me larf .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: That 's all right , Rogers . I have a sense of humour myself , or I should n't be here . ROGERSsuddenly sentimentalTalking about clothes , Mr. Manson , I often thinks in my ‘ ead as I 'd like to be a church clergyman , like master . Them strite-up collars are very becoming . Would n't you , Mr. Manson ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Would n't that be rather presuming , Rogers ?

sp.speaker: ROGERS
sp.p: Do n't you mek no mistike about it ! ‘ Ere !He grows confidential .You are a butler , ai n't you ? Ai n't you , now ? . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Something like that .

sp.speaker: ROGERS
sp.p: Well , perhaps master ‘ as n't allus been as ‘ igh — See ! O ’ course , I do n't know , but they do s'y as ‘ e was once only a . . . Wot oh ! ‘ Ere ‘ e is !

div.stage: The VICAR 'S voice is heard off .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I shall be in to breakfast at a quarter to nine . Do n't wait for me , dearest .He enters hurriedly from door , right , watch in hand . He has on his cassock and biretta .So awkward — Both my curates down with the whooping-cough ! To-day , too ! Just when I was expecting . . .

div.stage: As he goes up stage , left of table , MANSON comes down , right , with serviettes . The VICAR wheels round slowly , facing him . Observing his astonishment , ROGERS steps forward with explanation .

sp.speaker: ROGERS
sp.p: It 's the new butler , sir . Mr. Manson , sir .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Surely , I — I 've seen you somewhere before . MANSONlooking at himHave you , sir ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Hm ! No , I can n't quite . . .

sp.speaker: ROGERS
sp.p: Beg pardon , sir : getting on for eight .He hands him a small silver paten upon which there is a piece of bread .VICARTaking it mechanicallyHm ! These mysteries are not always helpful . . . Anyway , I 'm glad to see you , Manson . When did you arrive ?

div.stage: He begins to break the bread into fragments whilst talking .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Early this morning , sir . I should have come sooner ; but I had a little trouble down at the Customs .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Indeed ! How was that ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: They said something about the new Alien Act , sir .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Of course , of course . Er . . . You speak English remarkably well .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I have seen a good deal of the English , one time and another .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: That 's good : it will save a lot of explanation . By-the-bye . . . My old friend in Brindisi , who recommended you , writes that you bore a very excellent character with your late employer in India ; but there was one matter he did n't mention — No doubt you will recognise its importance in a clergyman 's family — He never mentioned your religion .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I can soon remedy that , sir . My religion is very simple . I love God and all my brothers . VICARafter a pauseGod and your brothers . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Yes , sir : all of them .The VICAR stands thoughtful for a moment . He places the paten on the table , beside him .VICARslowlyThat is not always so easy , Manson ; but it is my creed , too .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Then — Brother !

div.stage: Rapt in thought , the VICAR takes his profferred hand mechanically .
MARY enters . She is a slim young girl in her teens , the picture of rosy sweetness and health .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Good-morning , Uncle William ! Oh ! . . . I suppose you 're Manson ? I must say you look simply ripping ! How do you do ? My name 's Mary .She offers her hand .MANSONkissing itA very dear name , too ! MARYembarrassed , blurtingWe were wondering last night about your religion . I said . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Mary , my child . . .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: You do n't look like a cannibal . After all , even the devil is n't as black as he 's . . . Oh , I beg your pardon : perhaps I 'm rude .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Yes , indeed you are . Do n't take any notice of our little feather-brain , Manson .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I say , has uncle told you who 's coming to-day ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Not about Uncle Josh ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: T-t-t ! You must n't call your uncle Joshua that ! It is irreverent . He may resent it .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: You know , you 'll make me positively dislike him ! Just fancy , Manson , meeting an uncle whom you 've never so much as set eyes on before ! I do n't even know what he looks like .

div.stage: She is looking MANSON in the face . He returns her gaze curiously .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Then — you have a surprise in store .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: You ought to be awfully interested ! You will , when you hear where he comes from !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I am — interested .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Then guess who he is !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Guess — when I know already ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Oh , Uncle Joshua is n't his only name — do n't you think that ! He 's a very important person , I can tell you ! His name 's on everybody 's lips ! MANSONdrylyReally !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Ca n't you guess ? . . . Think of the very biggest person you ever heard of in this world !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: In this world : that sounds rather like . . . Does he give free libraries ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I can n't say I ever heard of that ; but he does things quite as wonderful ! Listen ! What do you think of the BISHOP OF BENARES ! ! MANSONunimpressedOh , it 's the — Bishop of Benares , is it ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I must say , you do n't seem very surprised ! Surely you 've heard of him ? He comes from India . MANSONquietlyI happen to know him .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: No , really : this is most interesting !

lg.l: As a man might know his own soul , sir — As they say in
India . His work has been mine , so to speak .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Bless me , you will know him better than I do . I have never seen him since I was quite a little lad . MARYwith prodigious solemnityJust you think , Manson ! He 's my uncle — my own father 's brother !

div.stage: MANSON is now up stage between the two .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Your brother , sir ? VICARferventlyI am grateful to God for it , Manson : he is .

div.stage: MANSON regards him calmly for a moment : then he turns inquiringly towards Mary .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Then — Miss Mary ? . . . VICARquicklyOh , my niece is the daughter of — of my other brother .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I see : two brothers ? VICARshortlyYes , yes , I have : I — I had . MANSONresuming his work at the tableThank you , sir : it 's always helpful , coming to a new place , to know who are — and who are not — the family connections .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Come , Rogers ! My poor brethren in the church are waiting . I must see to their necessities at once .He starts for the door .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Pardon me , sir .He hands him the bread which , among those necessities , he has forgotten . The VICAR looks at him a moment in troubled thought , and then goes out , followed by ROGERS .ROGERSat doorI 'll be back to ‘ elp you in with the breakfast , Mr. Manson .Exit .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Now , Manson : let 's talk ! You 've got nothing more to do ? . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Not till breakfast .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Then come over here , and make ourselves comfy .They go over to the settee : she plumps herself down , gathering her legs up into a little bunch . He seats himself beside her .Now ! Tell me everything you know about the Bishop of Benares !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: What — Uncle Josh ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Ssh — ssh — ssh ! That 's naughty , you know ! You heard what Uncle William said ! . . . Do you think he 'd very much mind if I called him Uncle Josh ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: You may take it from me , that you may call him whatever you like .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: That 's all very well ; but you 're not Uncle Joshua !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: No ? . . . MARYhotlyNo , you 're not !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Well , since you 're so certain . . . MARYwith convictionI 'm perfectly certain he 'll never stand a kid like me cheeking him and calling him names ! Uncle William 's quite right ! . . . And that 's why I 've made up my mind that I sha'n ' t like him , after all !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Indeed , I hope you will !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Do you believe in liking people simply because they 're uncles ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Perhaps I 'm a prejudiced person .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I know exactly what he 'll be — goody-goody , is n't he ? You know — religious , and all that !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: God forbid ! MARYfearfullyOh , perhaps he 's the other sort — like auntie 's brother ! He 's a bishop — the Bishop of Lancashire . You see , I 've heard a lot about bishops in my time , and they 're not always quite nice men .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: And what sort is the Bishop of Lancashire ?

lg.l: Well , I do n't think I ought to tell you ; but I once heard
Uncle William call him a devil !— And he 's a clergyman !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Your Uncle Joshua 's reputation is exactly opposite .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: There is that ; everybody speaks awfully well of him .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I do n't think I would go so far as that : some people blackguard him abominably .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: No !— Who ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: His clergy , chiefly .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: His clergy ! They must be dreadfully wicked men !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: No — only blind : perhaps , also , a little deaf . But between the two they manage to make his work very difficult .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Why ? What do they do ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: It 's partly what they do not do .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Oh , I see — lazy .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Not precisely — they work : they are not idle ; but they serve other masters .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Such as whom ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: The Bishop of Lancashire . MARYafter a pause, I always thought he was such a great success out there . The papers have been full of it — of the millions of people who follow him about : they say they almost worship him in some places . What kind of people are they ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Just common people .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: And then , all that talk of die great churches he built out there ! . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Churches ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Yes ; did n't he ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: He built one .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: What 's it like ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Those who have seen it say there is nothing like it on earth . MARYeagerlyHave you seen it ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I was there when he built it .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: From the very beginning ? MANSONsolemnlyFrom the beginning .

div.stage: MARY pauses before speaking : then she says , slowly .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I hope I shall like him . Is he — is he anything like you ?

div.stage: MANSON regards her silently for a moment .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: How is it that you know so little about him ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Well , you see , I only heard yesterday .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I thought you said his name was on everybody 's lips .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: You do n't understand . I mean , I never knew that he had anything to do with me — that he was my father 's brother .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Did n't he know ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Who — father ? Oh , you see , I. . . I do n't know my father . . . . . . Uncle William did n't know anything about it until yesterday .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Hm ! That is strange , too !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: There 's a bit of a mystery about it altogether . Would you like to hear ? It is rather like a fairy-tale .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: It must be . Yes , do go on .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: It was all through Uncle William 's Restoration Fund . You see , our old church is in a perfectly rotten state of decay , and naturally it would take a lot to repair it : so uncle thought of starting a Fund — Yes ! Was n't it clever of him ?— I addressed all the envelopes . Would you believe it , we could n't get a single halfpenny ! Is n't it a shame ?— Such a nice old church , too !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: How was that ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: That 's the question ! People have been most rude ! Oh , the letters we have had ! The funny thing is , for all their fault-finding , they none of them agree with each other !— Some say the foundations are all wrong : some do n't like the stained-glass windows ; but if you ask me . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Yes , what do you think ?

lg.l: Well , uncle wo n't hear of it ; but I can n't help thinking old
Bletchley is right . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Who 's he ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Oh , he 's a dreadfully wicked man , I know that — He 's the quack doctor in the village : he 's — he 's an atheist ! . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Well , what does he think is the matter ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: He says it 's the DRAIN !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: The — the drain ? . . .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Um ! You know , in spite of what uncle says , there is a smell : I had it in my nose all last Sunday morning . Up in the choir it 's bad enough , and round by the pulpit — Ugh ! I can n't think how uncle stands it ! That 's why the people wo n't come to church — They say so : they stand in the market-place listening to old Bletchley , instead of listening to uncle and trying to be good . The odd thing Is , it must be that very same drain that 's causing the trouble in uncle 's study — That 's his study out there , where they 've been digging : it 's where he writes his sermons . You know , I 've noticed the smell for some time , but uncle got so cross whenever I mentioned it , that I learned to hold my tongue . At last , auntie smelt it , too , and that soon brought the men in ! Ugh ! Perhaps you 've . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I have ! But what has all this to do with . . .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Do n't get impatient : it 's all part of the story . . . . Well , we thought we should have poor dear Uncle William perfectly ill . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Because of the drain ? . . .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: No , because of the Fund . He tried everything : all his rich friends , bazaars , jumble-sales , special intercessions — everything ! And nothing seemed to come of it ! Then at last , yesterday morning , he was reading the newspaper , and there was a long piece about the Bishop of Benares . Uncle read it aloud to us . Suddenly , in the middle , he broke off and said : Look at the power this chap seems to have at the back of him ! I wish to God I had some of it ! He had scarcely said it , when there was a rat-tat at the door : it was the postman ; and what do you think ? IT WAS A LETTER FROM THE BISHOP OF BENARES ? MANSONanticipating the criticsWhat a coincidence !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Is n't that wonderful ? Is n't it just like a fairy-tale ? Wait a bit . There 's more yet . . . Here 's the letter : uncle gave it me for my autographs . . .

div.stage: She fishes it out from her pocket . MANSON reads it aloud , slowly and clearly .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: “ I shall be with you during to-morrow morning . If any one will help me , I will restore your church . Your brother , Joshua . ” MARYpointingAnd there , do you see , underneath , in brackets : The Bishop of Benares .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Dear me , dear me , just those few words !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Was n't it like an answer to prayer ? Auntie saw that at once ! And the odd part about it is , that Uncle William did have a brother Joshua who went away and got lost in India years and years ago ! And to think that he was who he was all the time ! To think of him never writing until yesterday ! To think that before the day is out he will be sitting down here , perhaps in this very place , just like . . .

div.stage: She breaks off suddenly , gazing at him ; for his eyes have taken a strange fire .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Just like I am now . . . MARYfalteringlyYes . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Talking to you . . .

lg.l: MANSON
, Mary . . .
MARY
Who are you ? . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I am . . .He is interrupted by the great bell of the church , which tolls the Sanctus . After the third stroke , he continues .I am the servant in this house . I have my work to do . Would you like to help me ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: What shall I do ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Help to spin she fairy-tale . Will you ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I will .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Then keep the secret — Remember ! And wish hard .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Do you believe in wishing ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Everything comes true , if you wish hard enough .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: What shall I wish for ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: What have you needed most ? What have you not had ? Think it out .

div.stage: Enter AUNTIE in a negligee morning gown . She has a preoccupied air . She carries her husband 's coat over her arm .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Oh , I heard you had arrived . I hope they gave you something to eat when you came in .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Thank you , ma'am : it will do later .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Mary . . . Dearest . . .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Oh , I beg your pardon , auntie dear , I . . .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Dreaming again !Putting her arm round her .Come , I want you to put your uncle 's coat by the fire . He will be cold , coming out of that draughty church . MARYhugging herYou darling ! I believe you think of nobody but uncle in the world !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: And you , sweetheart : you come next — a very near next ! Now , run along .MARY takes the coat to the fire .Surveying the tableThat 's very nice , Manson , very nice indeed ! Perhaps , just a little further this way . . . .Removes flowers .My husband is so fond of them . Ye-es ; and I wanted things particularly nice this morning . . . MARYat the fire , looking upI thought you said you — you did n't expect him till twelve-thirty ! . . . AUNTIEabsorbedWhom ? MARYchucklingThe — the Bishop of Benares .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE

sp.p: Oh , Moses !Roaring , and indicating his breakfast .You ‘ av ’ blarst you ! BISHOPmistaking the gesticulationThank you , you are very kind . I think I will . I could get nothing on the journey but a cup of coffee and a bun .

div.stage: He sits at the table without ever having perceived MANSON , who has nevertheless been serving him .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Yus , you look as if you fed on buns !Throughout the play the audience will understand where the BISHOP does , and where he does not , hear by his use or non-use of the ear-trumpet . Perhaps the reader will be good enough to imagine these occasions for himself , as he may have observed a reluctance on the part of the author to encumber the text with stage directions .BISHOPeating , and at the same time addressing the becassocked ROBERTAnd you must not think , on account of the little coolness between us , that I have not followed your career with great interest — very great interest ! Your scholastic achievements have been most praiseworthy — especially under the unfortunate circumstances . . . . Although , by-the-way , I cannot at all agree with your gloss on Romans fourteen , twenty-three ; Katakekritai either means damned or nothing at all . ROBERTgesticulatingIt was ‘ im as said damned !

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: No , no , sir : it is perfectly indefensible !

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: I 'll use what langwidge I like ! BISHOPwarmingYou said katakekritai . . .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: I never did , I tek my oath !

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: My dear sir , I learned my Greek at Shrewsbury , before you were born ! Do n't argue , sir !

lg.l: Oo is argufying ? . . . Talking to me about yer
Katama-what-d'youhYpppHeNcallhYpppHeNit !

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: We had better drop the subject ! . . . Boeotian ! After all , it is not precisely the matter which has brought us together . And that reminds me . . .Trumpet .Has he come yet ?

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Oo ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Your brother , of course .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: My brother ! Oh , you 'll see ‘ im soon enough !

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: I gather from your remark that he has not arrived yet . Good ! The fact is , I should like a preliminary discussion with yourself before meeting your illustrious brother .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Then you 'd better look slippy !

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: I beg your pardon ? . . . ROBERTwith a flap at the trumpetGo on : you ‘ eard .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Of course , the financial undertaking is considerable : it 's not like an investment , where there is some reasonable hope of a return : it 's merely a matter of charity ! The money 's — gone , so to speak .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Yus , I 've noticed that about money , myself .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: At the same time , I should like my name to be associated with your brother 's , in so worthy an enterprise . . . ROBERTmildly sarcasticYou do n't say !

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: And then again , I trust — I say I trust — I am not impervious to the more sacred obligations involved ; but . . .

div.stage: He gropes blindly for bread .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: I allus notice that sort of ‘ igh talk ends with a “ but ” . . .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Naturally , I should like to learn a little , beforehand , of your brother 's views . From what I gather , they are not altogether likely to coincide with my own . Of course , he is an idealist , a dreamer . Now , under these circumstances , perhaps . . . Eh , what — Oh ! Bless my soul !MANSON has been offering him bread for some time . He has just tumbled to the fact of his presence . He rises .My — my Brother from Benares , I presume ?

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: What , my pal , ‘ is brother ! Oh , Je'oshaphat !

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Ten thousand pardons ! Really , my eyesight is deplorable ! Delighted to meet you ! . . . I was just observing to our charming host that — er — Humph ! . . . Bless me ! Now what was I . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Something about your sacred obligations , I believe .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: May I trouble you again ?

div.stage: MANSON gravely fixes the ear-trumpet in his ear .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: That 's right : stick the damned thing in ‘ is ear - ‘ ole , comride ! MANSONthrough the trumpetYour sacred obligations .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Precisely , precisely ! Er — Shall we sit ?They do so . The BISHOP looks to MANSON to begin . MANSON , failing him , the spirit begins to work within himself .Well — er — - speaking of that , of course , my dearly-beloved brother , I feel very seriously on the matter , very seriously — as I am sure you do . The restoration of a church is a tremendous , an overwhelming responsibility . To begin with , it — it costs quite a lot . Does n't it ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: It does : quite a lot .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Hm , yes — yes ! . . . You mentioned Sacred obligations just now , and I think that on the whole I am inclined to agree with you . It is an admirable way of putting it . We must awaken people to a sense of their sacred obligations . This is a work in which everybody can do something : the rich man can give of the abundance with which it has pleased Providence specially to favour him : the poor man with his slender savings need have no fear for the poverty of his gift — Let him give all : it will be accepted . Those of us who , like yourself , my dear brother — and I say it in all modesty , perhaps myself — are in possession of the endowments of learning , of influence , of authority — we can lend our names to the good work . As you say so very beautifully : sacred obligations . By-the-way , I do n't think I quite caught your views as to the probable cost . Eh , what do you think ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I think that should depend upon the obligations ; and then , of course , the sacredness might count for something .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Yes , yes , we 've discussed all that . But bringing it down to a practical basis : how much could we manage with ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: What do you say to — everything you have ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: My dear sir , I 'm not talking about myself !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Well — everything the others have ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: My dear sir , they 're not fools ! Do discuss the matter like a man of the world !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: God 's not watching : let 's give as little , and grab as much as we can !

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Ssh ! My dear brother ! Remember who 's present !He glances toward Robert .However . . .Coughs .We will return to this later . I begin to understand you .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Yus : you think you do !

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: At the same time , I do think we ought to come to some general understanding ; we must count the cost . Now , from all accounts , you have had some experience of church-building out in India — not that I think the extravagance for which you are credited would be either possible or desirable in this country — oh , no ! Thank God , we know how to worship in spirit and in truth , without the aid of expensive buildings ! However , I should like to hear your views . How did you manage it ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Sacrifice .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Of course , of course ; but practically . They say it 's an enormous concern !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: So it is .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Well , what would such an establishment as that represent ? In round numbers , now ? MANSONcalmlyNumberless millions .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Numberless mil . . . !He drops his fork .My dear sir , absurd ! . . . Why , the place must be a palace — fit for a king !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: It is !

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Do you mean to tell me that one man alone , on his own naked credit , could obtain numberless millions for such an object as that ? How could you possibly get them together ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: They came freely from every quarter of the world .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: On the security of your own name alone ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: No other , I assure you .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: For Heaven 's sake , tell me all about it ! What sort of a place is it ? MANSONseriouslyAre you quite sure you can hear ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Perhaps your voice is not quite so clear as it was . However . . .He wipes the inside of the ear-trumpet , and fixes it afresh .Now ! Tell me about your church .During the following speech the BISHOP is occupied with his own thoughts : after the first few words he makes no attempt at listening : indeed , the trumpet goes down to the table again in no time . On the other hand , ROBERT , at first apathetic , gradually awakens to the keenest interest in what MANSON says .MANSONvery simplyI am afraid you may not consider it an altogether substantial concern . It has to be seen in a certain way , under certain conditions . Some people never see it at all . You must understand , this is no dead pile of stones and unmeaning timber . It is a living thing . BISHOPin a hoarse whisper , self-engrossedNumberless millions !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: When you enter it you hear a sound — a sound as of some mighty poem chanted . Listen long enough , and you will learn that it is made up of the beating of human hearts , of the nameless music of men 's souls — that is , if you have ears . If you have eyes , you will presently see the church itself — a looming mystery of many shapes and shadows , leaping sheer from floor to dome . The work of no ordinary builder ! BISHOPtrumpet downOn the security of one man 's name !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: The pillars of it go up like the brawny trunks of heroes : the sweet human flesh of men and women is moulded about its bulwarks , strong , impregnable : the faces of little children laugh out from every corner-stone : the terrible spans and arches of it are the joined hands of comrades ; and up in the heights and spaces there are inscribed the numberless musings of all the dreamers of the world . It is yet building — building and built upon . Sometimes the work goes forward in deep darkness : sometimes in blinding light : now beneath the burden of unutterable anguish : now to the tune of a great laughter and heroic shoutings like the cry of thunder .Softer .Sometimes , in the silence of the night-time , one may hear the tiny hammerings of the comrades at work up in the dome — the comrades that have climbed ahead .There is a short silence , broken only by the champing jaws of the BISHOP , who has resumed his sausages . I 'm only an ‘ og ! . . . S'pose there 's no drain ‘ ands wanted in that there church o ’ yours ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Drains are a very important question there at present .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Why , I 'd be cussin ’ over every stinkin ’ pipe I laid .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I should make that a condition , comrade . ROBERTrising , he pulls off the cassock ; goes to fire for his coat : returns : drags it onI do n't know ! Things ‘ av ’ got in a bit of a muck with me ! I 'm rather like a drain-pipe myself .

sp.p: What 's that ?

sp.speaker: ROBERT

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Of what ?

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: ‘ Ell .Spelling .H , E , double L , ‘ ell .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Well , my dear sir , I think I ought to !

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Then , go there ! Aymen . . . Now I 'll go an ’ ‘ av ’ a look at our Bill 's drains , damn ‘ is eyes !

div.stage: He goes out through the main door , repentant .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: The scoundrel ! Did you hear what he said ? I shall certainly report him to his bishop !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I do n't think I should . His bishop does n't mind a little plain speech now and again .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: A little plain speech ! Do you think it 's right for a clergyman to — to direct me to perdition ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I think you are making a mistake : the man who gave you your — direction is not a clergyman . He 's a scavenger .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: A scavenger !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Yes — looks after drains .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Do you mean to tell me that I 've been sitting down to breakfast with a common working-man ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Yes ; have you never done that before ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: My dear sir , whatever do you take me for ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: A bishop of God 's church .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Precisely ! Is it your custom to breakfast with working-men ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Every morning . You see , I 'm prejudiced : I was one myself , once .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: You ? . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Yes — a long time ago , though : people have forgotten .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: But , my dear brother , I am perfectly sure you never told people to go to . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Oh yes , quite frequently : it would shock you to learn the language I really did use . Perhaps , under the circumstances , it might be advisable to drop the subject at this point . BISHOPemphaticallyI most certainly agree with you there ! After all , it is a digression from the purpose for which we are here ! . . . Let me see , then : where were we ? . . . Oh yes , I remember — Although , by the way , it was very ill-advised of you to speak your mind so openly in that man 's presence ! However . . . To resume our — how shall I call it ?— our — little understanding , eh ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: That describes it most accurately .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Now , you said , Let 's give as little , and grab as much as we can . Of course , that is a playful way of putting it ; but between ourselves , it expresses my sentiments exactly .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I knew that when I said it . BISHOPdelightedMy dear brother , your comprehension makes my heart warm . I trust our relations may always remain as warm .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Oh , warmer , warmer !

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Very well then , to business ! I tell you , candidly , I agree with you , that there is no necessity for sinking anything of our own in the concern : nothing ever comes of that sort of reckless generosity ! If people want a church , let them make some sacrifice for it ! Why should we do anything ? I am sure you will appreciate my candour ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: At its full value . Go on .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: At the same time , there is no reason why we should throw cold water upon the project . On the contrary , we might promote it , encourage it , even lend it the influence of our patronage and our names . But on one understanding !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: And that ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: That it is extended — imperialised , so to speak : that it is made the vehicle of a much vaster , of a much more momentous project behind it !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: You interest me intensely . Explain .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: I will .He looks around to assure himself that they are alone .There is in existence a society , a very influential society , in which I happen to have an interest — very great interest . Hm ! I am one of the directors . I may say that it is already very well established , financially ; but it is always open to consider the — extension of its influence in that way .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: And the name of the society ?

lg.l: Rather long , but I trust explicit . It is called “ The
Society for the Promotion and Preservation of Emoluments for the
Higher Clergy . ”

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I do not seem to have heard it named before .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Well , no : its movements have always been characterised by a certain modesty . It is an invisible society , so to speak ; but I can assure you its principles are very clearly understood — among the parties most concerned .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: And your project ?

lg.l: Affiliate the subsidiary question of the building of the
Church , with the larger interests of the Society .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Yes , but since people have already refused to subscribe to the more trivial project . . .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: They have not been properly approached . My dear sir , in order to awaken public generosity , It is necessary to act like men of the world : we must have names . People will subscribe to any amount , if you can only get the right names . That Is where you come in .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I ! Do you propose to place my name at the head of your — prospectus ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: My dear sir , invaluable ! Did n't you say yourself that you brought in numberless millions , on your own credit , out there in India ? Why should n't you do the same in England ? Think of your reputation , your achievements , your name for sanctity — Not a word , sir : I mean it ! . . . Why , there 's no end to the amount it would bring in : it would mean billions ! Well , what do you say ? MAMSONslowlyLet us clearly understand one another . I am to lend you my name — just my name — and you are to do all the rest . BISHOPquicklyOh yes : I 'd rather you kept out of the business negotiations !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: It is rather a dangerous name to play with ! BISHOP , I take that responsibility entirely upon myself !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: And when all 's over and done with , what are we going to gain out of the transaction ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: We shall have to come to some private settlement between ourselves .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: When ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Oh , hereafter .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Hereafter , then .Enter AUNTIE and VICAR by door to right .AUNTIEoffLeave him to me , William ! I 'll soon settle the matter !Entering .The man must be possessed of some evil spirit ! . . . Why — it 's my brother James ! . . .

div.stage: MANSON has risen , and is now the butler once more . He speaks into the ear-trumpet .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Your sister and the vicar , my lord . BISHOPbehind table , risingAh ! Well , Martha !— No , no , no , if you please !He restrains her approach .Observe the retribution of an unchastened will . You have never seen my face for sixteen years ! However , like a cloud , I blot out your transgressions from this hour ! And so this is your husband ?— Not a word , sir ; not a single word !— the sausages were delicious , and your place has been most agreeably occupied by your brother !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: My brother ! Then you . . . What do you mean ? BISHOPtestilyI mean what I say , sir ! Your brother , my brother , our brother here , of course , our Oriental brother !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: James , you are making a mistake : this is our new butler — our Indian butler .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Your Indian — WHAT ?

div.stage: He stands cogitating horribly until the end of the act , facing towards MANSON .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: What has made him like this ? He seems possessed !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: He is ! . . . I have just been having some trouble with another devil , ma'am .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Meaning , of course . . . What has become of him ? MANSONwith his eyeHe is cast out forever .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Where is he now ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: He walks through dry places seeking —he probes her soul— other habitations .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Manson ! This is your doing ! Oh , you have saved us !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I am trying to , ma'am ; but , God knows , you make it rather difficult !

div.stage: A change comes over her face , as the curtain slowly falls .

div.head: THE THIRD ACT

stage.stage: As the curtain rises , the scene and situation remain unchanged ; but attention now centres in the Bishop , who appears to be struggling apoplectically for speech .

BISHOP [ bursting ] . Before we proceed a step further , I have a most extraordinary request to make ! The fact is , you interrupted me in the middle of a most engrossing spiritual discussion with my . . . that is to say , with your . . . in short , with that person standing over there ! My request is , that I be permitted a few minutes further conversation with him — alone , and at once !

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: ) With Manson ! . . . MANSON . ) With me ! . . .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Not a word ! I know my request will appear singular — most singular ! But I assure you it is most necessary . The peace , the security of a human soul depends upon it ! Come , sir ! Where shall we go ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Have I your permission , ma'am

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Certainly ; but it is most extraordinary ! MANSONcrossingThen I think this way , my lord , in the drawing-room . . .He leads the way .BISHOPfollowingAnd you may be sure , my good fellow , I will give anything — I say , anything — to remedy your misapprehensions ! Hm !

div.stage: They go into the drawing-room , right , MANSON holding the door for the other to pass .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Martha ! It 's no use ! I can n't do it ! AUNTIEpreoccupiedCa n't do what , William ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Behave towards that man like a Christian ! He stirs some nameless devil like murder in my heart ! I want to clutch him by the throat , as I would some noisome beast , and strangle him ! AUNTIEslowlyHe is greatly changed !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: It is you who have changed , Martha . You see him now with different eyes .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Do I ? I wonder ! . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: After all , why should we invite him here ? Why should we be civil to him ? What possible kinship can there be between us ? As for his filthy money — how did he scrape it together ? How did he come by it ? . . .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Yes , William , that 's true , but the opportunity of turning it to God 's service . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Do you think any blessing is going to fall upon a church whose every stone is reeking with the bloody sweat and anguish of the human creatures whom the wealth of men like that has driven to despair ? Shall we base God 's altar in the bones of harlots , plaster it up with the slime of sweating-dens and slums , give it over for a gaming-table to the dice of gamblers and of thieves ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Why will you exaggerate , my dear ?— It is not as bad as that . Why do n't you compose yourself and try and be contented and — and happy ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: How can I be happy , and that man poisoning the air I breathe ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: You are not always like this , dear ! . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Happy ! How can I be happy , and my brother Robert what I have made him !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: We are not talking of Robert : we are talking of you ! Think of our love , William — our great and beautiful love ! Is n't that something to make you happy ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Our love ? It 's well you mention it . That question had better be faced , too ! Our love ! Well , what of it ? What is love ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Oh , William , you know . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Is love a murderer ? Does love go roaming about the world like Satan , to slay men 's souls ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Oh , now you 're exaggerating again ! What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I mean my brother Robert ! What has love done for him ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Oh , Robert , Robert — I 'm sick to death of Robert ! Why can n't you think of yourself ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Well , I will ! What has love done for me ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: William ! . . .

div.stage: The slightest pause . The scene takes on another complexion .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Do you remember that day when I first came to you and told you of my love ? Did I lie to you ? Did I try to hide things ? Did I despise my birth ? Did you ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: No , no , William , I loved you : I told you so .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Did you mind the severance from your family because of me ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Did n't I always say that I was proud to be able to give up so much for you , William ? . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Yes , and then what followed ? Having given up so much for me , what followed ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: My dear , circumstances were too strong for us ! Ca n't you see ? You were not made to live out your life in any little odd hole and corner of the world ! There was your reputation , your fame : you began to be known as an author , a scholar , a wonderful preacher — All this required position , influence , social prestige . You do n't think I was ambitious for myself : it was for you .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: For me — yes ! And how do you imagine I have benefited by all your scheming , your contriving , your compromising , your . . .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: In the way I willed ! I am glad of it ! I worked for that — and I won ! . . . Well , what are you troubling about now ? VICARslowlyI am thinking of the fact that there has been no child to bless our marriage , Martha — that is , no child of our very own , no child whose love we have not stolen .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: My dear . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: We have spoken about it sometimes , have n't we ? Or , rather — not spoken !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: William , why will you think of these things ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: In those first days , dearest , I brought you two children of our own to cherish , little unborn souls crying for you to mother them — You have fostered only the one . That one is called the Scholar . Shall I tell you the name of the other ? AUNTIEafter a momentYes . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I hardly know : I hardly dare to name him , but perhaps it was — the Saint .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: What I have done , William , has been done for love of you — you only — you only in the world !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Yes : that 's what I mean !

div.stage: The thought troubles her for a moment ; then she paces up and down in agitated rebellion .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: No ! I can n't believe it ! I can n't think that love is as wrong as you say !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Love is a spirit of many shapes and shadows : a spirit of fire and darkness — a minister of heaven and hell : Sometimes I think the very damned know love — in a way . It can inform men 's souls with the gladness of high archangels , or possess them with the despair of devils !She suddenly stands still , struck by the echo in his last phrase .Yes ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE

sp.speaker: MARY

sp.p: Then you 're not a . . .

div.head: THE FOURTH ACT

stage.stage: As the curtain rises , the scene and situation remain unchanged . After a moment , Mary comes down to the settee , left , and buries her face in the cushions , weeping . Shortly , the handle of the drawing-room door is turned , and from within there emerges a murmur of voices , the Vicar 's uppermost .
VICAR [ within ] . Very well , then , after you have finished your letters ! . . .

div.stage: The voices continue confusedly : MARY rises quickly and goes into the garden .

The VICAR enters and goes to the mantel-piece weariedly : a moment later , AUNTIE . ] BISHOP [ within ] , I shall only be about twenty minutes . AUNTIE [ entering ] . All right , do n't hurry , James : you have all the morning .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Hm ! When he has finished his letters !

All your hopes , all your enthusiasms , about to be realised ! Now , it only remains to gain your brother Joshua 's approval and help , and the scheme is complete !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Supposing he — does n't approve of the scheme ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: My dear , he must approve : he will see the advantages at once . I think James made that perfectly clear ! . . . And then , look at the opportunities it creates for you ! Not only the church , William , the beautiful big church of your dreams , with the great spires and flashing crosses and glorious windows ; but a much larger sphere of usefulness than you ever dared to dream ! Think of your work , William , of your great gifts — even James had to acknowledge them , did n't he ?— Think of the influence for good you will be able to wield ! Ah ! And then I shall see my beloved , himself again — No more worry , no more feverish nights and days , none of the wretched frets and fancies that have been troubling him all this morning ; but the great Scholar and Saint again , the master of men 's souls , the priest in the congregation !

sp.p: Suppose you try and forget me for a moment . Do you think you can ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: William , that 's unkind ! Of course I can n't .

sp.p: It might mean the salvation of my soul .

sp.p: Oh , William ! Now you 're going to begin to worry again !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Oh no : I 'm quite calm . Your brother 's powers of reasoning have left me philosophical . . . . Tell me , are you quite sure that you have grasped the full meaning of his project ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Of course ! You think no one can understand a simple business dealing but men ! Women are every bit as clever !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Well , then , this project : what was it ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: James explained clearly enough : the affiliation of your brother 's scheme with that of the society he mentioned .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Yes — what society ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: The Society for the Extension of Greater Usefulness among the Clergy . . . . It was an admirable suggestion — one that ought to appeal particularly to you . Have n't you always said , yourself , that if only you had enough money to . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Did you happen to realise his explanation as to the constitution of the society ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: To tell the truth , I was n't listening just then : I was thinking of you .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: The financial possibilities of the scheme — Did his eloquence on that point escape you ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Figures always bore me , and James uses dreadfully long words .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Did you hear nothing of profits ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: I only heard him say that you were to . . .
