sp.p: Well , did n't it strike you that throughout the entire discussion he spoke rather like a tradesman ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: My dear , you can n't expect everybody to be an idealist ! Remember , he 's a practical man : he 's a bishop .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Did n't it strike you that there are some things in this world which are not to be bought at any price ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: My dear William , bricks and mortar require money : you can n't run a society without funds !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Yes , but what of flesh and blood ? What of reputation ? What of a man 's name ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Whatever do you mean now ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Did n't his proposal practically amount to this : that we should turn my brother Joshua 's name and reputation into a bogus Building Society , of which the funds were to be scraped together from all the naked bodies and the starving bellies of the world , whilst we and our thieving co-directors should collar all the swag ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Now , that 's exactly where I think you are so unjust ! Did n't you yourself refuse , before he spoke a word , to let him put a penny of his own into the concern ? I must say , you were unnecessarily rude to him about that , William !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Yes , and did n't he jump at the suggestion !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: He offers to give his patronage , his influence , his time . All he asks of your brother is his bare name .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Yes , and all he asks of me is simply my eloquence , my gift of words , my power of lying plausibly !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: William , he is offering you the opportunity of your life !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Damnation take my life !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: William , why are you so violent ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Because violence is the only way of coming to the truth between you and me ! AUNTIEnow thoroughly afraidWhat do you mean by the truth , William ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I mean this : What is the building of this church to you ? Are you so mightily interested in architecture , in clerical usefulness , in the furtherance of God 's work ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: I am interested in your work , William . Do you take me for an atheist ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: No : far worse — for an idolater !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: William . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: What else but idolatry is this precious husband-worship you have set up in your heart — you and all the women of your kind ? You barter away your own souls in the service of it : you build up your idols in the fashion of your own respectable desires : you struggle silently amongst yourselves , one against another , to push your own god foremost in the miserable little pantheon of prigs and hypocrites you have created ! AUNTIErousedIt is for your own good we do it !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Our own good ! What have you made of me ? You have plucked me down from whatever native godhead I had by gift of heaven , and hewed and hacked me into the semblance of your own idolatrous imagination ! By God , it shall go on no longer ! If you have made me less than a man , at least I will prove myself to be a priest !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Do you call it a priest 's work to . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: It is my work to deliver you and me from the bondage of lies ! Ca n't you see , woman , that God and Mammon are about us , fighting for our souls ? AUNTIEdeterminedlyListen to me , William , listen to me . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I have listened to you too long !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: You would always take my counsel before . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: All that is done with ! I am resolved to be a free man from this hour — free of lies , free of love if needs be , free even of you , free of everything that clogs and hinders me in the work I have to do ! I will do my own deed , not yours ! AUNTIEwith deadly quietnessIf I were not certain of one thing , I could never forgive you for those cruel words : William , this is some madness of sin that has seized you : it is the temptation of the devil !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: It is the call of God ! AUNTIEstill calmlyThat 's blasphemy , William ! But I will save you — yes , I will — in spite of yourself . I am stronger than you .

div.stage: They look at each other steadily for a moment , neither yielding ,

lg.l: Then I accept the challenge ! It is God and I against you ,
Martha !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: God and I against you , William .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: So now — for my work ! AUNTIEquietlyYes : what are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Three things .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Yes — and they ? . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Tell Mary everything : send for my brother , Robert : and then — answer that monster in there . AUNTIEfearfullyWilliam , you would never dare ! . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Look ! . . .

div.stage: MARY re-enters from the garden .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Auntie ! Uncle ! I want to speak to you at once — both of you !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: You are just in time : I wanted to speak to you at once .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Is it important , uncle ? Mine 's dreadfully important .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: So is mine . AUNTIEquicklyLet the child speak , William . Perhaps . . .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I hardly know how to begin . Perhaps it 's only my cowardice . Perhaps it is n't really dreadful , after all . . . AUNTIEtroubledWhy , what are you thinking of , Mary ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: It 's about something we have never spoken of before ; something I 've never been told . VICARsearchinglyYes ? . . . AUNTIEfalteringlyYes ? . . .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I want to know about my father .

div.stage: There is a short silence . The VICAR looks at AUNTIE .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Now : is God with you or me , Martha ?

lg.l: What do you mean by that ? Is it very terrible , uncle ?
lg.stage: He stands silent , troubled . MARY crosses him , going to AUNTIE .
lg.l: Auntie . . .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Do n't ask me , child : I have nothing to tell you about your father .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Why , is n't he . . .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: I have nothing to tell you .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I have .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: William ! . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I have , I say ! Come , sit here , Mary .She sits to left of him , on the settee . AUNTIE is down stage on the other side of him .Now ! What do you want to know about your father ? MARYpassionatelyEverything there is to know !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: William , this is brutal ! . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: It is my work , Martha !— God 's work ! Have n't I babbled in the pulpit long enough about fatherhood and brotherhood , that I should shirk His irony when He takes me at my word ! Now : what put this thought into your head to-day ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I do n't know . I 've been puzzling about something all the morning ; but there was nothing clear . It only came clear a few minutes ago — just before I went into the garden . But I think it must have begun quite early — before breakfast , when I was talking to my — to Manson ,

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Manson ! . . .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: And then , all of a sudden , as I was sitting there by the fireplace , it came — all in a flash , you understand ! I found myself wishing for my father : wondering why I had never seen him : despising myself that I had never thought of him before .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Well , what then ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I tried to picture him to myself . I imagined all that he must be . I thought of you . Uncle William , and Uncle Joshua , and of all the good and noble men I had ever seen or heard of in my life ; but still — that was n't quite like a father , was it ? I thought a father must be much , much better than anything else in the world ! He must be brave , he must be beautiful , he must be good ! I kept on saying it over and over to myself like a little song : he must be brave , he must be beautiful , he must be good !Anxiously .That 's true of fathers , is n't it , uncle ? Is n't it ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: A father ought to be all these things .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: And then . . . then . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Yes ? . . .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I met a man , a poor miserable man — it still seems like a dream , the way I met him — and he said something dreadful to me , something that hurt me terribly . He seemed to think that my father — that perhaps my father — might be nothing of the sort !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Why , who was he — the man ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: He would n't tell me his name : I mistook him for a thief at first ; but afterwards I felt very , very sorry for him . You see , his case was rather like my own . He was wishing for his little girl .

div.stage: There is a short silence .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Where did you meet with him ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Here , in this room .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: When was this ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: A few minutes ago — just before you came in .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Where is he now ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: He said good-bye . He has gone away .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: For good ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Yes , I think so : I understood him to mean that .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Was he — a rough-looking man ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Dreadfully ; and he swore once — but afterwards he said he was sorry for that .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Did he frighten you at all ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: No , not exactly frighten : you see , I felt sorry for him . VICARslowlyAnd he would n't tell you his name ? . . .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: No : I asked him , but he would n't .

div.stage: The VICAR ponders this for a moment .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Now , is it God with you or with me , William ?

div.stage: For a moment this unnerves him . Then setting his teeth together , he faces his task stubbornly .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Have you any idea about this man ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: How do you mean — any idea ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: As to why he put this doubt into your head about your father .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: He seemed to be thinking about himself , and how unworthy he was of his own little girl .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Did he say — unworthy ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: That 's what I think he meant . What he said was that perhaps my father was n't good enough to be your brother , uncle . That 's not true , is it ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: No , by Heaven ! That 's not true ! MARYrapturouslyOh , I knew it , I knew it ! VICARin an agonyStop ! You do n't understand !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I understand quite enough ! That 's all I wanted to know !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Listen , child ! Listen ! I mean that it is I who am not worthy to be called his brother .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: William , this is absurd ! MARYsnuggling up to himIs n't he a dear ? VICARfreeing himselfListen to me , Mary : I have something awful to tell you : try and bear it bravely . You will hate me for it — never love me again ! . . . No , listen ! . . . Supposing your father were — not what you imagine him to be ? . . .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Uncle , did n't you just say . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Supposing that wretched man you spoke with just now were right , after all ! What would you say ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Uncle ! . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Supposing he were one upon whom a11 the curses of the world had been most cruelly visited — his poor body scarred and graven out of human semblance ; his soul the prey of hate and bitterness ; his immortal spirit tortured and twisted away from every memory of God ! What would you say ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Uncle , it would be terrible — terrible !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: What will you say , then , to the man who has brought him to such ruin ? What will you say to that man being God 's priest ? What word of loathing have you for the thief who has stolen the love of another man 's child , for the murderer who has slain his brother 's soul ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Uncle , do you mean . . . do you mean . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I mean that I am the man !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: You ! . . . AUNTIEpassionatelyIt is not true ! It is a lie ! It 's entirely your father 's own fault !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I do n't understand . Why should Uncle William lie to me ?

lg.l: He is overwrought : he is ill . It is like your uncle
William to take upon himself another man 's wickedness !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Then , that is true , at least : my father is a wicked man ! . . .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: I do n't want to speak about your father !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: He is nothing that I have wished him to be : not brave . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Yes — that at least ! MARYturning towards himBeautiful ? . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: What do you mean by beautiful ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: You know what I mean : What you once said God was , when you called Him beautiful .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I have no right to judge your father .

div.stage: She perceives the evasion .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Not even — good ? . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: He is what I have made him . I and no other !

div.stage: She stands looking at him piteously .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: There is another — I ! I kept them apart : I poisoned your uncle against him : I took you away from him : It was I who kept you in ignorance of your father !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Why ? . . .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Because he stands in the way of my husband 's happiness ! Because , even , he is your father ! Because I hate him ! I could almost wish him dead !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Martha ! . . .

div.stage: There is a long pause .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Then I have nobody , now . It 's no use wishing any more .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Mary . . .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: No ! . . . I want to be alone .

div.stage: She goes out into the garden . They follow her out with their eyes .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: So ! God has revealed His partisanship !— He has beggared us both !

div.stage: AUNTIE considers this for a moment . Then , with sudden determination , she rises .

lg.l: I am not going to be beggared without a struggle for it ,
William !

div.stage: She moves briskly across to the bell .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: What are you going to do , Martha ? AUNTIE ,flashing round passionately , before she can ring the bellDo you think I am going to stand by and see your life wrecked — yours and that child 's ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: We are not the only persons concerned , Martha .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: As far as I care , you are !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: And what of Robert ? . . .

lg.l: Robert ! That 's what I 'm going to see to now !
There 's only one way of dealing with a brute like that !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: What 's that ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Pack him off to Australia , Africa — anywhere , so long as we are never pestered with him again ! VICAR , Do you think you 'll get him to go ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Oh , I 'll find the money ! A drunkard like that will do anything for money ! Well , he shall have plenty : perhaps he 'll drink himself to . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: By Heaven , but I say no !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: By Heaven , but I say yes ! It 's about time I took things in hand again ! Do you think I 'm going to risk that child learning everything ? She knows more than enough already ! Providentially , she does not know the worst !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: And what knowledge do you consider Providence has so kindly spared her ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: The knowledge who that man was ! She shall never know , if I can have my way !She rings the bell again , impatiently .Why does n't he come ? Why does n't he come ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Manson .

div.stage: Enter MANSON by the main door . There is a subtle change in the manner of him , a look in his eye , as of the servant merging in the master .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: You rang .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Yes , come in , Manson . I want to have a little confidential talk with you — confidential , you understand . MANSONeying herIf you please . I expected this .

div.stage: He has the air of a judge . She hurries on , unheeding .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Manson , you saw everything . You were here when that dreadful creature arrived .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Which ?

lg.l: Why , my husband 's brother , Robert . Did n't you tell me ,
William , that Manson heard everything he said ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Then you will know the wretched plight we are in . Manson , it 's terrible . I want your help . By-the-way , you have not spoken about it to the other servants ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I am always most discreet . AUNTIEtouchedThank you , Manson , thank you : I felt that I could trust you . It 's to prove my trust that I 've sent for you now . Perhaps I 'd better begin by explaining everything quite clearly , so that you . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: There is no need . I know everything already . AUNTIE , Everything ! How ? . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: A certain gift of divination — mine by birth . And , besides , you forget that I had a long conversation with your brother-in-law after master left the room .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: What ! Whilst my brother was here ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Yes : we all three had breakfast together .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Breakfast together ! Then James has heard all !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Not quite all . You may have observed that your brother is a little deaf .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: But surely — What did he think ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: He mistook him for your husband .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: My husband !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Your brother is also a little blind , remember . AUNTIEdelightedThen James never found out ? . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Oh yes : I took care to undeceive him on the point .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Good gracious ! How did he take it ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: At first , a little angrily ; but , after a while , some few poor words of my own chanced to move him to more — profitable meditation .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Manson , you 're perfectly wonderful ! I respect you very , very much !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: It is not enough . I shall require more . AUNTIEembarrassedOh , of course , I shall be glad to do anything that . . . Why , what do you mean ? . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I mean that service such as mine demands a greater recompense !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: You may be sure that anything in reason . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: It must go beyond that !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Well , what do you ask ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: The uttermost obedience , loyalty , and love !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Manson , how dare you ! By what right . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: By my own right !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: This is insolence ! What right do you mean ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: The right of understanding , the right of purpose , and the right of will !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: You force me to speak angrily to you ! Do you forget that you are my servant ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: No ! And , therefore , it is my office to command you now ! Sit down , and hear me speak !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: He has been sent to help us ! Martha , this is God !

lg.l: Over here , please .
AUNTIE . I . . . I . . .

div.stage: MANSON still points . She wavers as in a dream , and at length moves mechanically across the room , obeying him .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Now , let me tell you exactly why you have sent for me here . There is a strange and wretched turmoil in your soul : you have done wrong , and you know it — but you do n't know all ! You would keep what miserable little right you have by bolstering it up with further wrong . And you have sent for me to help you in that wrong !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: How dare you say that ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Have n't you sent for me to help you in your plans about his brother , Robert ? AUNTIEfaintlyWhat plans ? . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: The plan of banishing him further from your lives than ever ! The plan of providing for him ! The plan of patching up his bitter wrongs with gold !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: How did you know that ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I know you ! What , do you think that God 's eyes are like your brother 's — blind ? Or do you think these things can be done in darkness without crying aloud to Heaven for light ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: I am here to work my will , not yours !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: What gain do you hope to bring yourself by that ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: I am not thinking of myself ! I am thinking only of my husband 's happiness !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Behold the happiness you have already brought him !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: There is the child ! It would break her heart !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: What is her heart but broken now — by you ? AUNTIE , Robert himself would be the first to repudiate any other plan .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Have you tried him ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Of course not ; but he must see the impossibility .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: What impossibility ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: The impossibility of having him here : the impossibility of letting him see the child : the impossibility of him and his brother ever meeting again !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Is that your only difficulty ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Only difficulty ! What , would you have me welcome him with open arms ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Yes , and heart , too !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Have him here , entertain him , treat him as a guest ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: As an honoured guest !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: In this house ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: This house .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Good Heavens ! what else ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Sweep and garnish it throughout , seek out and cleanse its hidden corners , make it fair and ready to lodge him royally as a brother ! AUNTIEdesperatelyI wo n't do it ! I can n't ! I can n't !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: With my assistance , you can !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Manson , how can we bring it about ? AUNTIE , I dare n't ! I dare n't !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I dare ! I will !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: In God 's name , how is it possible ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Make me the lord and master of this house for one little hour !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: By Heaven , yes !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: And you ? You ? . . .

div.stage: She falters a few moments : then , utterly broken down , she whispers , feebly .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Then first TO CLEANSE IT OF ITS ABOMINATIONS !

div.stage: The BISHOP enters from the drawing-room . He carries a letter in his hand .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Well , here is the letter I have written to the secretary of our Society : I have explained everything quite nicely ; and have warned him , of course , against doing anything definite in the matter until we have consulted your dear brother . Now . . . Eh , what ? Oh ! . . .

div.stage: MANSON has tapped his ear , peremptorily : he fixes his ear-trumpet .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I bear you a message from the master of this house . Leave it .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Really , I . . . . . . . Most extraordinary ! Hm !He blows down the ear-trumpet , and afterwards wipes it very carefully with his handkerchief . MANSON stands , as though carven in marble , waiting for him to fix it again .Now : again , please .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: You are no longer necessary . Leave this house .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: You scoundrel ! You impudent scoundrel ! You . . . You . . . Give me back my five-pound note ! MANSONpointing to the fireIt is invested for you .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: I will have it back at once !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Hereafter , was the arrangement .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Mr. Smythe ! Where are you ? Do you hear what this blackguard says ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I endorse it , every word .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Martha ! . . .She turns away from him as from some horror of sin . The BISHOP stands dumfounded for a moment or two : then he boils over .Now I see it all ! I 've been trapped , I 've been tricked ! Martha , this is all your doing ! Brought me here on a trumped-up story of relationship with the Bishop of Benares , to insult me ! Oh , what would that godly man say if he heard of it !— And he shall hear of it , believe me ! Your infamy shall be spread abroad ! So this is your revenge , sir —he turns to the VICAR— your revenge for the contumely with which I have very properly treated you , sir ! Now I understand why I was made to sit down and eat sausages with a butler — yes , sir , with a butler and a common working-man ! Oh ! I could die with shame ! You have bereft me of all words ! You . . . You . . . You are no scholar , sir ! And your Greek is contemptible ! . . .He crosses to AUNTIE .Martha ! You are no sister of mine henceforward !Going , he returns to her .Anathema maranatha !He bounces up to the door , but turns back again for a last word with MANSON .And I have one word for you , sir ! You are a scoundrel , sir — a cheat , an impostor ! And if I could have my way with you , I would have you publicly whipped : I would visit you with the utmost rigour of the law : I would nail you up , sir , for an example !

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: I have encountered similar hostility before , my lord — from gentlemen very like your lordship . Allow me . . .

div.stage: He opens the door , his eyes flashing .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Do n't trouble , sir . I can get my hat and my stick and my portmanteau for myself ! I can do very well without your assistance — thank God !

div.stage: He stumps out . MANSON closes the door after him , barring it , as it were , with his great left arm . He lifts the other arm slowly , as commanding silence . After a moment the front door is heard slamming noisily .
AUNTIE sinks , weeping , upon the settee . The VICAR goes over to comfort her . The uplifted hand of MANSON assumes the BISHOP 'S sign of blessing as the curtain slowly falls .

div.head: THE FIFTH ACT

stage.stage: As the curtain rises , the scene and situation remain unchanged .

div.stage: There is heard a Ring of the Bell . All three turn their heads , alert .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: If it 's my brother . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Which ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I meant — the Bishop of Benares ; but . . . AUNTIEhand on his arm , apprehensivelyWilliam . . .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: It wants ten minutes of the time you said you expected him .Goes to door : turns .Only ten minutes .

div.stage: He goes out , closing the door softly .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Ten minutes ! . . .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: We shall never be able to do it , William ! How can we possibly undo the work of all these years in ten minutes ? It wants a miracle .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: We must make the attempt , somehow .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Yes — yes : how ? Oh , I have been blind — blind !She walks across the room in agitation .Where has he gone , I wonder ? We do n't even know that — where he is ! VICARmaking a movementPerhaps Manson . . .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: No , no , no : it must be ourselves . . . Ten minutest — And no assistance on his side : we can n't expect it , after our treatment of him . He will hate me most of all : there 's the chief difficulty ! . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: You would say me , if you had seen his face and heard his voice this morning !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: God help us . God pity us !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Amen . . . Then , there 's the child , too ! That difficulty must be faced .

lg.l: Yes — no escape ! We shall have to pay the whole debt ,
William : I see that .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Who knows ! Perhaps the child will have to pay most , when all is done .

lg.l: The innocent for the guilty — yes . . . Oh , William ,
William , can you ever forgive me ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: There is much to forgive , both sides , Martha . My sin has been greater than yours . You have only loved unworthily in blindness : I have seen clearly and been a coward .Enter MARY from the garden .Mary ! . . .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Let me speak , uncle . I have been thinking , out there in the garden — thinking very hard : I 've been trying to put things together again and make them straight ; but it 's still very difficult . Only there 's one thing — I 'm sorry I was unkind just now : I did n't mean it : you are everything I have — everything I have ever had ; and as for what uncle said — about himself , I mean — I can n't believe it . No , I 'm sure there 's a mistake somewhere ; and mistakes can always be put right , if we only help one another and mean it . Shall we try , uncle ? Shall we , auntie ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: If it 's not too late ! . . .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: It can n't be too late , auntie dear , if we all wish very hard . I was a coward to give up wishing . That was my sin , too !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: God knows , I wish , Mary ! . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: And I ! . . .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: And , indeed , I do ! . . . Now , I 've been thinking : I 've been trying to look the worst in the face . Supposing my father is the wicked man you say — the very , very wickedest man that ever lived , do n't you think if we tried to love him very much it might make a difference ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: What made you think of that , Mary ? . . . MARYsimplyIt 's what you taught me , uncle , in your sermons .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I taught you ? . . .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Yes : and , besides , there 's another reason . . . I 've been thinking of the poor man I met this morning .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: ) Yes . . . VICAR . ) What of him ? . . .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: He said he was a wicked man , and at first he looked so dreadfully wicked , I believed him ; but when I began to look at him closely , and heard him talk about his little girl , everything seemed different ! I could no more believe him , than I can believe you , uncle , when you say such awful things about yourself ! I believe he was a much better man than he ever dreamed ! And so I think we might find my father just the same , if he was properly loved and looked after ! VICARwith determinationThen listen to me , Mary : I have something to tell you : that very man you spoke to . . .

div.stage: ROGERS enters , his face betraying signs of his morning 's affliction .

sp.speaker: ROGERS
sp.p: Beg your pardon , sir ; but . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Yes , Rogers : what is it ?

sp.speaker: ROGERS
sp.p: Mr. Manson sent me , sir ; it ai n't my fault ! . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Do explain yourself , Rogers !

sp.speaker: ROGERS
sp.p: Well , sir , it 's a bit orkard : it 's . . . I really do n't know what you 'll say , sir , I do n't really . . . VICARimpatientlyCome , come , come , what is it ?

sp.speaker: ROGERS
sp.p: It 's a man , sir !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Well , there 's nothing very extraordinary in that . Wants to see me , eh ?

sp.speaker: ROGERS
sp.p: Yes , sir ; and what 's more , Mr. Manson told me to bring ‘ im in !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Well , why do n't you ?

sp.speaker: ROGERS
sp.p: ‘ E 's mucked up to the eyes , sir ! Bin down the drains ! It 's the same chap as come an ’ made so free ‘ ere this mornin ’ !

div.stage: There is a general rapturous excitement .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Praise God ! Shew him in at once ! ROGERSflabbergastedWhat ! In ‘ ere , sir ? . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Come , come , come !ROGERS 'S cosmos is fast slipping away : he crawls abjectly to the door : his hand on the knob , he turns once more a face of bewildered inquiry upon the VICAR , who snaps his fingers impatiently .ROGERSwith a sickly smile‘ E 's just outside , sir .Opening the door , he whines .Oh , do come in .

div.stage: ROBERT enters , amply fulfilling the lad 's description . The latter lags out , nauseated with the world .
ROBERT stands up stage , in the middle : AUNTIE and VICAR , down stage , one on either side . MARY with her aunt .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Can I be ‘ eard civil in this ‘ ouse , if I speak a few words ?They make a movement as towards him .‘ Old back ! Do n't you come near me ! Do n't you so much as speak till I 've done ! . . .To Auntie and Vicar respectivelyYou do n't know me : you do n't know me . . . Understand ? There 's no one ‘ ere as knows oo I am , excep ’ one little gel — ‘ er over there . Now , keep quiet ! ‘ Ere ! . . .MARY goes up to him .Tell ‘ em oo I am .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Why , it 's my friend — the man I was telling you about ! The man who looks after the drains !

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: That 's about it : I 'm the drain-man , see ? Thought you might be mistakin ’ me for — summat else , if you was n't told . Now you know .

div.stage: MARY 'S face , as she returns , bears the first dawn of an idea . The VICAR lifts a hand of warning to AUNTIE .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Go on .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: That 's what I come ‘ ere to talk abaht — my job . P'r ' aps you 'll think as it ai n't a tasty subjic , before a lot o ’ nice , clean , respectable people as never ‘ ad anythin ’ worse on their fingers than a bit of lawn-dirt , playin ’ crokey ; but some one ‘ as to see to the drains , some one ‘ as to clear up the muck of the world ! I 'm the one . An ’ I 'm ‘ ere to tell you about it . AUNTIEinvoluntarilyOh ! . . .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: You do n't like that , ma'am ? ‘ Urts your feelin 's , eh ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Yes ; but not in the way you mean ,

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: But you know , you really are a little unpleasant !

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: I 'm not ‘ ere to be pleasant , young leddy : I 'm ‘ ere to edicate you .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Yes , I think I see ! AUNTIEbreathlesslyGo on : go on !

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Well , I come to this ‘ ouse this mornin ’ , I do n't mind ownin ’ it , in a rotten bad frame of mind : I ‘ ad a little job on ‘ and — a job a bit above my ‘ ead , an ’ it got me dahn an ’ worried me : yus it did — worried me . That young leddy ‘ ll tell you wot I was like when she fust saw me : I looked that bad , she thought I come to steal summat ! Well , p'r ' aps I did , arter al !— summat as I ‘ ad no right to , summat as do n't properly belong to a streaky swine like me . That was when she fust saw me ; but I was wuss before that , I tell you strite ! MARYself-consciouslyWhat changed you ?

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: A bloke I met , miss , as knowed me better than I knowed myself . ‘ E changed me .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: ) Manson ! . . . VICAR . ) Manson ! . . . MARY . ) Oh , I thought , perhaps . . .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Do n't know ‘ is name ; ‘ e was a fair knock-aht — Got togs on ‘ im like an Earl 's Court Exhibition . . . ‘ E changed me : ‘ e taught me my own mind ; ‘ e brought me back to my own job — drains .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Yes . . .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Funny thing , ma'am , peopled born different : some 's born without noses in their ‘ eads , worth speakin ’ of . I was n't — I can smell out a stink anywhere . AUNTIEfascinatedI am sure you can . This is most interesting ! ROBERTwarmingMoment I stuck my ‘ ead in this ‘ ouse , I knowed as summat was wrong in my line , and I ses to myself : Wot oh , ‘ e ai n't such an awl-mighty liar , arter all — that 's drains ! An ’ drains it was , strike me dead — arskin ’ your pawdon ! MARY , Now , did n't I always say . . .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Yus , miss , you 're one o ’ the nosey uns , I can see ! Well , soon as ole Togs got done with ‘ is talk , I got my smeller dahn , follered up the scent , an ’ afore I knowed where I was , I was in it , up to my eyes !— Out there in the room with the blood-red ‘ eap o ’ books ! Blimey , you never did see ! Muck , ma'am !— Just look at my ‘ ands ! Ai n't that pretty ? ‘ Owever , I got there , right enough , I do n't fink ! Fancy I put that little bit strite afore I done !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Oh , this is too beautiful of you ! . . . ROBERTburning with enthusiasm , and manifestly affected by her appreciationWait a bit : I got more yet ! Talk abaht bee-utiful !— That bit was on'y an ash-pan ! Look ‘ ere , ma'am , I got the loveliest little job on as ever yer soiled yer ‘ ands in ! . . .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Oh , do tell us ! . . .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: ) Yes , do ! . . . VICAR . ) Yes , yes ! . . .

div.stage: A splendid rapture infects them all .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: I followed up that drain — I was n't goin ’ to stick till kingdom come inside your little mouse - ‘ ole out there : No , I said , Where 's this leadin to ? What 's the ‘ ell-an-glory use o ’ flushin ’ out this blarsted bit of a sink , with devil-know-wot stinkin ’ cess-pool at the end of it ! That 's wot I said , ma'am ! . . .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Very rightly ! I see ! I see ! . . .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: So up I go through the sludge , puffin ’ an ’ blowin ’ like a bally ole cart - ‘ orse — strooth , it seemed miles ! Talk abaht bee-utiful , ma'am , it ud ‘ a ’ done your ‘ eart good , it would really ! Rats !— ‘ Undreds on em , ma'am : I 'm bitten clean through in places ! ‘ Owever , I pushed my way through , somehow , ‘ oldin ’ my nose an fightin ’ for my breath , till at last I got to the end — and then I soon saw wot was the matter ! . . . It 's under the church — that 's where it is ! I know it 's the church , cos I ‘ eard “ The Church 's One Foundation ” on the orgin , rumblin ’ up over my ‘ ead ! Well , I . . .

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Yes . . . yes . . .

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Why do n't you go on ? . . .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: You 'd never guess wot I saw there , not if you was to try from now till glory ‘ allelooyer ! . . . The biggest back - ‘ ander , I ever did ‘ av ’ , swelp me ! . . .They hang on his words expectantly .IT AIN'T NO DRAIN AT ALL ! ALLbreathlesslyWhy , what is it , then ? . . . ROBERT . IT 'S A GRIVE !

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: A grave ! . . .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Yus , one o ’ them whoppin ’ great beer-vaults as you shove big bugses ’ corpses inter ! What d'yer think o ’ that now ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: ) Oh ! . . . AUNTIE . ) Horrible ! . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I seem to remember some tradition . . . ROBERT , You 'd ‘ a ’ said so if you 'd seen wot I seen ! Talk abaht corfins an ’ shrouds an ’ bones an ’ dead men gone to rot , they was n't in it , wot I saw dahn there ! Madame Twosoes is a flea-bite to it ! Lord !— I never thought there could be such a lot o ’ muck an ’ dead things all in one place before ! It was a fair treat , it was , I tek my oath ! . . .

div.stage: Rapturously ] . Why — why , it may cost a man ‘ is LIFE to deal with that little job !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: My God ! The thing 's impossible !

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Impossible ! Means a bit of work , that 's all !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Why , no one would ever dare . . .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Dare ! Why , wot d'you think I come ‘ ere for ? . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: You ! . . .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Yus — makin ’ myself unpleasant . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Do you mean . . . Do I understand . . .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: I mean as I 've found my place , or I do n't know a good thing when I see it !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: What ! To go into that dreadful vault , and . . .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Why not : ai n't it my job ?

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: But you said — perhaps — death . . .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: It 's worth it , it 's a lovely bit of work !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: No , ten thousand times , no ! The sacrifice is too much !

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: You call that sacrifice ?— It 's fun : not ‘ arf !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I had rather see the church itself . . .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: What , you call yourself a clergyman !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I call myself nothing : I am nothing — less than nothing in all this living world !

lg.l: By God , but I call myself summat — I 'M THE DRAIN-MAN ,
THAT 'S WOT I AM !
VICAR
You shall not go ! . . .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Why , wot is there to fear ? Ai n't it worth while , to move away that load o ’ muck !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: The stench — the horror — the darkness . . .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: What 's it matter , if the comrides up above ‘ av ’ light an ’ joy an ’ a breath of ‘ olesome air to sing by ? . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Hour by hour — dying — alone . . .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: The comrides up in the spans an arches , joinin ’ ‘ ands . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Fainter and fainter , below there , and at last — an endless silence ! . . .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: ‘ Igh in the dome , the ‘ ammerin 's of the comrides as ‘ av ’ climbed aloft !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: William , there is yet one other way ! . . .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Yes , yes , I see : I see ! . . .To ROBERTThen — you mean to go ?

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: By ‘ Eaven , yus !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Then , by God and all the powers of grace , you shall not go alone ! Off with these lies and make-believes ! Off with these prisoner 's shackles ! They cramp , they stifle me ! Freedom ! Freedom ! This is no priest 's work — it calls for a man ! . . .He tears off his parson 's coat and collar , casting them furiously aside . He rolls up his sleeves .Now , if you 're ready , Comrade : you and I together !

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: God 's might go with you , William ! Accept him , Christ !

div.stage: There is a silence . Then ROBERT speaks with slow consideration .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: I — do n't — know . It 's dangerous , you understand !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I go with you .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: This ai n't psalms an ‘ ymns an ’ ole maids ’ tea-parties , mind you ! It may mean typhoid !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I understand .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Rats .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: They do n't leave you alone : they got teeth , remember — poison in ‘ em !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I will go with you .

div.stage: A slight pause . Then ROBERT , dropping into a quite ordinary tone , says .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Then let 's ‘ av ’ summat so eat , an ’ get along . There 's nuthin ’ more to say . MARYinspiredYes , there is !

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: What do you mean , miss ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I mean that I understand : that I know who you are .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: Me ? . . . MARYsimplyYes , you are my father .

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: ‘ Ow the everlastin ’ did you know that ? MARYgoing up to himBecause you are my wish come true : because you are brave , because you are very beautiful , because you are good !

sp.speaker: ROBERT
sp.p: My little kid ! My little kid !

div.stage: They embrace each other .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Robert !Taking his left hand

sp.speaker: AUNTIE
sp.p: Brother !Taking his other hand .

MANSON and ROGERS re-enter with table-cloth , etc ., for lunch .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Come along , Rogers . Take that end .

sp.p: What , already ! Let 's have him in at once !

div.stage: MANSON deliberates with the flowers before he speaks .

sp.p: He is here .

div.stage: The VICAR crosses towards him .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: What do you mean ? Where is he ?

div.stage: MANSON looks at him over the flowers .

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: Here .

div.stage: The VICAR steps back , gazing at him . After a moment he gasps .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: In God 's name , who are you ?

sp.speaker: MANSON
sp.p: In God 's Name — your brother .

div.stage: He holds out his hand . The VICAR takes it , sinking to his knees and sobbing as one broken yet healed .
